Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Versatile transcription activator-like effector libraries for genome-wide screens

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1351354
Bleris, Leonidas

The ability to perturb individual genes in genome-wide screening experiments has been instrumental in unraveling cellular and disease properties. The PI proposes to develop, optimize, and implement novel transcription-activator like effector (TALE) libraries and associated technologies. TALEs are proteins that can be engineered to target specific nucleotide sequences in mammalian cells and can act as activators or repressors of gene expression at the transcriptional level. While the TALE library technology holds promise for a wide range of applications, the emphasis of this proposal lies in the development and customization of TALE libraries for induced pluripotent stem (iPS) cell reprogramming.

From disease modeling to curing genetic diseases, the prospective iPS applications are endless. Considering the highly modular nature of TALEs and the versatility and ease of constructing these libraries, the technology is transformative and will spark a large number of novel biotechnology and medical applications. The results will be disseminated through publications in peer-reviewed journals, conference proceedings, and presentations at national and international conferences. The PI will develop a customized special topics class on systems biology and the role and properties of student networks and collaborative learning in education will be explored. In addition, the educational plan consists of several action items tightly integrated with research, including (a) support for the UT Dallas International Genetically Engineered Machine (IGEM) undergraduate synthetic biology team, (b) interfacing via internship opportunities with leading US research and science policy institutions, (c) annual seminar day at Collin Community College and a summer internship hosted in our lab, and (d) lab community service.
Due to the interdisciplinary nature of the project, this CAREER award by the Biotechnology, Biochemical, and Biomass Engineering Program of the CBET Division is co-funded by the Systems and Synthetic Biology Program of the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Our research contributions combine complex experiments and theory development. We aim to address scientific problems of broad significance and develop new technologies. Our contributions can be organized in the following categories: (1) mammalian synthetic biology, (2) genome editing technologies, and (3) biological network analysis.

(1) Mammalian synthetic biology:

  • Using a combination of synthetic biology experimentation in human embryonic kidney cells and quantitative analysis, we investigated the relationship between input genetic template abundance, microRNA concentration, and output under microRNA control (Quarton et al. npj Systems Biology and Applications, 4(6), 2018).
  • We presented a synthetic gene network architecture that operates as a biological decoder in human cells, converting 2 inputs to 4 outputs (Guinn et al. ACS Synthetic Biology, 3(8), 2014).
  • We studied the effect of negative feedback on global and local sources of uncertainty using synthetic circuits stably integrated in human cells (Shimoga et al. Molecular Systems Biology, 9, 2013).

(2) Genome editing technologies:

  • We introduced a coevolutionary framework to computationally unveil nonobvious molecular interactions in CRISPR systems and experimentally validated their functional role (Li et al. Biophysical Journal, 117(9), 2019).
  • We demonstrated that the PAM requirement can be exploited to specifically target single-nucleotide heterozygous mutations while exerting no aberrant effects on the wild-type alleles (Li at al. PLoS ONE, 11(1), 2016).
  • We introduced a methodology to control the copies and residence time of a gene product delivered in host human cells but also selectively disrupt fragments of the delivery vehicle (Moore et al. Nucleic Acids Research, 43(2), 2015).
  • We introduced and demonstrated the use of comprehensive and versatile transcription activator-like effector (TALE) libraries (Li et al. Scientific Reports, 4:4857, 2014).
  • We introduced a general purpose two-hybrid approach that can be customized to regulate the function of any TALE either using effector molecules or a heterodimerization reaction (Li et al. Scientific Reports, 2:897, 2012).

(3) Biological network analysis:

  • We presented a high-throughput CRISPR-based methodology for delineating the role of network edges. We demonstrate that network edges are critical to the function and stability of biological networks (Li et al. The CRISPR Journal, 1(4), 2018).
  • We used a combination of computational and theoretical approaches coupled to synthetic biology experimentation in mammalian cells to study direct and indirect connectivities in biological networks (Kang et al.  PNAS, 112 (41), 2015).
  • We introduced an experimental platform customized for the development and verification of reverse engineering and pathway characterization algorithms in mammalian cells (Kang et al. ACS Synthetic Biology, 2 (5), 2013).

 

Broader Impact

Teaching: I developed and teach the graduate level courses on "BMEN 6382: Systems Biology" and "BMEN 6374: Genes Proteins and Cell Biology for Engineers", the undergraduate course "BMEN 4310: Feedback Systems in Biomedical Engineering", and a graduate course on "BMEN 6V72: CRISPR and Genome Editing".

Undergraduate Research: I initiated the UT Dallas undergraduate International Genetically Engineered Machine (IGEM) team. IGEM is the premiere undergraduate synthetic biology competition. I established the UT Dallas IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society Student Chapter. In order to integrate science and engineering with K-12 education, our group delivered lessons in biology targeted at various age groups at a local summer camp for at-risk youth. Members of the Bleris Lab (2016 and 2018) participated in "Building with biology" and “Synthetic Biology” at the Perot Museum, a series of events that create conversations among scientists and public audiences about the emerging field of synthetic biology and its societal implications.

Dissemination of research: I am regularly invited to present my work in meetings (more than 20 invited talks/seminars). I also seek opportunities to present in DFW. 

Scientific Review and Review Panel Service: I regularly serve NSF as review panelist and remote reviewer. I am invited in at least 1 meeting per year at NSF. Over the past few years, I also regularly serve as a reviewer for NIH. I was first invited in 2016 and typically serve twice a year. I also review proposals for the Netherlands Organization for Scientific Research (NWO) and the Greek Ministry of Education, Lifelong Learning and Religious Affairs (THALIS program). I am an editor for Scientific Reports, an online open access scientific journal published by Nature Research. 

Scientific Meeting Service: I am actively involved with 3 annual workshops/meetings and I participate at the Annual AIChE meeting typically by chairing sessions. More specifically, I have been a co-chair and member of the organizing committee of the "International Mammalian Synthetic Biology Workshop" since its inception in 2013. I am also a member of the organizing committee of the "International Conference on CRISPR Technologies". Finally, I am a member of the organizing committee of the "Texas Symposium on Computing with Emerging Technologies".
